title: Boston just lost an $11 million decision in a discrimination case - Massachusetts news
text:
An employee of the City of Boston was awarded $10.9 million after a Suffolk Superior Court jury determined her supervisor had discriminated against her based on her race, The Boston Globe reported.
Chantal Charles, a senior administrative assistant in the Treasury Department, will receive $10 million in punitive damages, $500,000 for emotional distress, and $389,000 in additional pay, according to the Globe .
A city employee since 1986, Charles has African American and Haitian ancestry. She said the discrimination began in the 1990s when her supervisor, Vivian Leo, denied her overtime pay, schedule flexibility, and transportation benefits, and prevented her from using her management title. She also issued an unfavorable evaluation of her work after Charles reported the discrimination, according to the Globe .
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below “I hope that this jury verdict will convince the city to take a good hard look at [its] hiring practices,” Charles’s attorney Emma Quinn-Judge told the Globe .
A spokeswoman for Mayor Marty Walsh’s office told the Globe that the discrimination occurred under a previous administration, and the city will likely appeal the decision.
